response:
Urgent spinal MRI is needed to confirm the hemicord lesion and exclude surgically treatable compression, while brain MRI, CSF analysis and autoimmune/infectious blood tests help distinguish demyelinating, neoplastic and infectious causes; routine blood tests assess for inflammation, metabolic myelopathy and treatment safety, with CT or X-ray reserved if MRI is unavailable.

investigations = ["Urgent MRI of whole spine with gadolinium contrast", "MRI brain with gadolinium contrast", "Full blood count", "C-reactive protein", "Erythrocyte sedimentation rate", "Urea and electrolytes", "Liver function tests", "Blood glucose", "Serum vitamin B12", "Serum folate", "Serum copper", "Antinuclear antibody (ANA) and extractable nuclear antigen (ENA) panel", "Serum aquaporin-4 antibody", "Serum myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) antibody", "HIV serology", "Syphilis serology (treponemal test)", "Tuberculosis screening (e.g., Quantiferon-TB Gold)", "Lumbar puncture for CSF cell count, protein, glucose, oligoclonal bands, cytology and microbiology", "Plain X-ray of thoracic and lumbar spine", "CT of thoracic spine with contrast if MRI is contraindicated"]
